UNRELEASED GAME

 
 
 Note that all details for this game are preliminary. If you have information about this game, you are invited to edit this section or submit corrections.

 


Right now the only details about this item are the Shakes & Fidget: Das Kartenspiel name and what's included below.

Over The Alps board game was made in England as part of the Glevum Series in around 1930s. As the title suggests – it has a mountaineering theme, which is highlighted by the image on the box lid.

It is a simple race game, played with dice and counters. But what makes it more attractive is that the board – which is stored folded in the box needs to be stood up inside the box base to form a mountain. You start at the bottom of one side and the first person to reach 100 is the winner. You go up one side and then down the other. Instead of ‘squares’ on a regular board this one has numbered holes. The reason for this is that the counters slot into those holes. There are four 1½” high metal climbers. They actually look as if they are Boy Scouts. The figures are identical except that their shorts are different colours. They are red, yellow, green and blue.

No brakes. No speed limits. Just husky racing at its most extreme.

Gordon and Fraser Lamont say that Snow Tails was their favorite design of the past decade, so in celebration they've decided to revisit husky racing with Mush! Mush! - Snow Tails 2, a fast-playing follow up to Snow Tails that allows you to dive in for a single race or compete over a three-route championship—the choice is yours!

Mush! Mush! includes a massive oversized board with multiple tracks on both sides, new bonus movement, four polyresin buildings, proper scale model trees with bases, no brakes (as advertised above!) and less math, and gameplay that fits up to eight at the table—you and seven losers. Now hop on the sled and get moving!

item.description:
This is a waited sequel game of Struggle of Army Group Manstein, and Mansterin's last battle.

The game starts June 1942 at the start of Blau and end December 1942 at the start of Soviet counterattack.
The game uses the same engine as its predecessor. Each player selects his chits each turn, then draw chits one by one and activate part of the force designated by the chit.
This time, there's no special rule. The game rule is easier than Manstein's last battle.
The victory is determined by VPs mainly gained by control important cities. Of course, the most important one is Stalingrad.

From the designer:

The Universe is ending. Legends and Myths throughout the galaxy talk about a way to survive. The Oracle promises eternal life to the species that possesses it. The object of the game is to find the Oracle and hold it until the end of the game.

Players journey from planet to planet searching for useful items to aid them in their quest.
They will engage other players with diplomacy cards as well as facing them in player versus player combat.
Different weapon types include energy, physical, mental, fire, sound, and acid.
One on one combat starts at long range. If neither player has died combat progresses to medium and then short range.
Expect to be destroyed. There is no player elimination. Another agent of the species steps in to take the place of the deceased character.

There is a lot of variation in the initial setup. Replayability is built into the design.
After the Oracle is discovered, the universe begins to deteriorate. Planets start disappearing.
Resources become scarce and combatants are pushed together.

Oracle is an exciting fast-paced game that you will find yourself playing multiple times a session.

After Japanese daimyÅ Oda Nobunaga's forced suicide on June 21, 1582, other daimyÅs fight for power.
Note: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honn%C5%8D-ji_Incident
Each players represents lords from the period: Hashiba, Akechi, Shibata, Oda-Nobukatsu, Oda-Nobutaka, Sanhoushi, Takikawa, Uesugi, Mori, or Hojo.

The game uses Successors (AH, GMT) card-driven mechanics and can be played in 6 to 8 hours.
It is designed for 3 players in basic version (4 players with the expansion in GJ 49).

Tha map covers Shikoku to Kanto area.
The game starts in Tensho 10 (1582) and ends in Tensho 13 (1585).

Components:

 252 counters
 1 map
 64 cards

Mars Attacks: The Miniatures Game is a tabletop miniature wargame based on the humorous 1962 Mars Attacks trading card series from Topps in which aliens from Mars try to take over the planet of the humans — that is, Earth!

The game allows two (or more) players to take on the role of Martian invaders or the human resistance, then battle for the fate of the planet! You set your armies on the table board and move units of aliens or human soldiers to fight to achieve goals, either by defending your position or vaporizing your opponents. This tactical tabletop game features rules by veteran designer Jake Thornton and a host of stunning Mantic miniatures that can be used straight out of the box or painted to add even more character to your games.

- Martian Mayhem: Mars Attacks is full of wacky events and cinematic action made possible by the simple set of game mechanics that are very easy to learn, and by the game's Event Card deck.

- Story Driven Action: Follow our heroes during the battle of Greenville with fun playable scenarios, each with their own objectives: eliminate the enemy, capture the intelligence - escape the Martian invaders!

- Easy to play: Much like a board game, Mars Attacks is played on a gaming mat made of squares and players take it in turn to activate their models, choosing whether to move, shoot or fight in hand-to-hand combat.

- Simple Dice Mechanics: Shooting and hand-to-hand combat is made easy by rolling eight-sided dice to decide whether a weapon has hit its target, or whether the opponent manages to dodge out of the way.

- Highly Tactical: move a figure out from behind cover and you’re likely to get your model killed. Similarly, ganging up on an opponent or making use of a figure’s special abilities could be the difference between making a clean kill, or engaging in a frantic game of cat and mouse!

All of this is detailed in the comic-book sized Mars Attacks – The Miniatures Game rulebook which also includes a number of playable missions. These battles are fought in Greenville, a town brought to life through our stunning modular ruined scenery. You will fight amongst the devastated town capturing objectives such as intelligence and weapons - or with the sole goal of eliminating your enemy.

Whether you’re a veteran gamer or new to the hobby, you’ll be able to enjoy the fun of Mars Attacks, making it a game suitable for all ages.

item.description:
Westerly is a co-operative adventure game of westward expansion. Players select a character at the beginning of the game and try to get them to California in one piece...literally. In Westerly things can go from bad to worse in a matter of minutes and your character can be injured, maimed, left to die by the group or maybe just eaten by a bear or even your own party. Ayup that's right I'm talking about cannibalism. Fear not if it all goes wrong you can rejoin the party as a different character that hops into the wagon at the next town.

The game involves strategy and co-operation combined with a tongue in cheek approach to all the horrible things that can happen along the perilous route out west.

Tiles are played in order to navigate the group to California. The game space is split into three different tracks North, South and West. Encounter cards are drawn depending on which track the group is currently in. The group must then work together to select the best way to deal with the encounter and either reap the benefits or pay the consequences of their selection.

The road is treacherous filled with bandits, angry natives, predators, environmental dangers, and the list goes on. Westerly is comedic one minute and brutal the next. You never know what the exact party make up will be or what route you will have to take to go west.

Westerly is all about the story of you and your friends trying their best to make it out west and all the ridiculous things that can go wrong along the way. If ya manage to get there you will absolutely have a wild story to tell.

item.description:
Everybunny knows that rabbits love the countryside — and carrots, of course! The best carrots of all grow between the train tracks, but you have to keep an eye out for trains! Roll the dice and hop your rabbit to the best carrot patch; as long as you don't need to flee out of the path of the train, you can happily nibble away. Chomp, chomp, chomp...

In Karnickel, each player places his rabbit on the circular train track made of eight interchangeable tiles, sets the train engine on its start space, then takes turns rolling the custom dice. After you roll, set any die that shows the "train" out of play, then count up how many times each of the player colors appears on the remaining dice; you must move one of the rabbits (yours or another player's) clockwise around the track the full number of spaces. You then pass the rabbit dice to the next player. Players take turns, each time rolling only the dice passed to them and hopping the rabbits from tile to tile, trying to land on the tiles where they will be able to collect the most carrots.

When a player rolls only trains, the rabbit hopping has to stop as the train is ready to move! That player rerolls all seven dice, counts up the number of trains rolled, then moves the train that many spaces around the track. Every rabbit on a tile that the train moves through is scared away by the engine and hops off the track, failing to collect any carrots this time. All rabbits still on the track after the train moves — either because the train didn't reach them or because they were on one of the two tunnel tiles — get to grab 1, 2 or 3 carrots...or maybe lose one — exploding carrots are a risk!

Everyone then hops back onto the track, and the next player rolls all the dice to start a new round of play. Whoever has the most carrots when one player has at least eight carrots wins!

item.description:
Swedish trivia game (translation: "the super cool 90's). With questions relating to (predominately Swedish) 90's pop culture in TV, music and film.

The players divide into teams or compete individually. It is a party game where having fun is more important than keeping score, though one correct answer equals one point.

Muzicando is a card game about the rainbow colors and about musical instruments and notes. The deck consist of 56 cards 8 for each color of the rainbow. 7 cards have the musical notes from DO to TI and the eighth card is a representing a special personality like one of the followings:
Guido d'Arezzo, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Franz Liszt, Ludwig van Beethoven, Frederic Francois Chopin, Johann Sebastian Bach and Niccolo Paganini.
Guido d'Arezzo was a music theorist of the Medieval era. He is regarded as the inventor of modern musical notation (staff notation) that replaced neumatic notation and thus he is the most powerfull card in the game causing all the players to skip a turn when played giving an aditional turn to the one who played it. The other personalities are some of the best composers of clasical music and when played are causing some players to skip a turn,

The main goal in this game is to be the first to get rid of all the cards. The mechanism to get rid of them is to put them on the table in turns in some ways that depends of an auction made in the first phase of the game. The players can bid for on of the 4 ways to display the cards on the table. These are Sarabanda, Glissando, Parada and Muzicando.

item.description:
Swedish party game (translation "Girls' dinner").

A simple trivia game with 400 questions on topics like the perfect boyfriend, fun memories, sex and much more.

The game is more about having fun than keeping score, but as is customary in these types of games, one correct answer scores one point.

From the Avalanche Press website:

The liberation of France began with the Allied invasion on D-Day, 6 June 1944. From Sword, Gold, and Juno beaches, British Army troops fought their way across the hedgerows and rolling green hills, driving back Hitler’s Wehrmacht and SS forces. Fierce German resistance, featuring skilled use of tanks on the defensive, resulted in the loss of huge numbers of men and machines - but no loss of will. The promise of 1940 would be fulfilled.

Liberation 1944 is a complete game in the Panzer Grenadier series covering the fierce struggles of His Majesty’s forces through Operations Overlord, Goodwood, and Bluecoat. There are 41 new scenarios by designer Mike Perryman. Four new mapboards by artist Guy Riessen show the hedgerows, hills, towns and farmland of France. There are 517 playing pieces: 352 combat units and 165 markers.

Both sides bring swarms of tanks to your game table: Shermans and Fireflies, Cromwell and Churchills match up with Panthers, Panzer IV's, and Tigers.

Players assume the roles of aspiring chefs who are competing for the head chef position at the swanky Burger Blitz restaurant. Battle your way to the top by attacking other chef's reputations, enlisting the services of food minions, making magic in the kitchen, and getting your hands dirty by taking the plate to speed up your burger-making skills.

Burger Blitz's main mechanic is press-your-luck dice rolling. What you roll determines 6 different bonuses you can earn that round - Reputation, Burger Ingredients, Pepper, Mayo, Attack, and Tips.

In addition to dice, there are 24 minion cards which players can purchase. These minions give players permanent bonuses they can use every turn.

Finally there are magic cards. Magic cards are earned every time a player completes a full burger. These cards are powerful but can only be used once. Play a mayo token with a magic card to boost the effects even more.

Burger Blitz is easy enough for young children to learn but has enough depth and strategy to entertain seasoned gamers. Included in the rulebook are several variants recommended for more casual or more cutthroat games.

Tripods! is a competitive, strategy survival game set during a Martian invasion of Victorian London. Two to four players take control of a number of playing pieces representing the populace of the city and are trying to score as many points as possible by the end of the game. Points are awarded for helping citizens escape, keeping them alive until the Martians are destroyed and killing the Martian war machines.

The inhabitants of London have no say over the greater workings of the Martian invasion or the government's response to it, relying on garbled rumours and reports to keep them informed. Game plays out over a fixed narrative of eight 'Headlines', which reveal the next stage of the invasion and events within the narrative are controlled by a 'Tidings' deck which instructs the players how to manipulate the invaders and the military who are trying to counter the threat. The Tidings deck also contains the Red Creeper, which spread across the board as the game progresses. Once consumed by the alien plant a space is no longer safe from the Martian's terrible Death Ray. These Tidings can be manipulated by players through the use of five Character cards, each of which has a special ability and each of which can be used only once per game so timing must be chosen carefully.

Escape from London is achieved by leaving the board from one of five stations or the docks. As Headlines are revealed these escape routes begin closing and as the Martians grow more prolific, the Red Creeper spreads, the available military units dwindle and escape routes shut so the tensions build and players begin to turn on each other to compete for the few remaining avenues of exodus.

item.description:
Moose Hunt game made by Chaffee and Selchow (later Selchow & Righter) is a typical roll and move board game with wonderful graphics depicting a hunter and Indian killing moose.

The first player who crosses the "start" line wins the game.

Quinquereme is a light dice game loosely connected to the navies of ancient Rome. Each player has to complete twelve scoring categories in any order, e.g. three of a kind for numbers 1 to 6, four of a kind or a straight of consecutive numbers. Dice may be rolled up to three times per turn. Scoring may vary, dependent on how many throws a player has already used during his/her turn.

Three, four and five of a kind are referred as Triremes, Quadriremes and Quinqueremes. Players unable to assign their result to any of the available score categories have to 'sink' one of their ships (i.e. mark zero points in a category).

After all categories have been filled, points are added and the player with the most points wins. 
The game uses standard six-sided dice with roman numerals from I to VI.

item.description:
Super Fantasy is the first hack'n'slash board game in which up to six players take on the roles of brave and unique heroes. During each game, players embark on tricky and mighty quests into ever-changing dangerous caves and dungeons swarmed with monsters and terrible creatures that try to slaughter them, while heroes try to gain treasures as well as better equipment in order to complete the missions.

Since hordes of monsters repeatedly cross the path of our heroes, bloody clashes are inevitable in order to achieve victory! That is why Super Fantasy uses a simple yet unique dice-based system. Players have a pool of six dice to roll that they manage according to the action they want to perform (such as movement, attack, etc.) and its effectiveness. Each face of the dice shows either a 1, 2 or the Special Power symbol and the sum of the results shown represents the effectiveness of the action performed by the heroes. Every time the Special Power symbol occurs, the hero can choose to charge one of his abilities; once fully charged, the hero can unleash its power against the enemies!

Super Fantasy features double-sided modular board pieces for creating countless scenarios combinations, six mighty heroes and three unique and powerful abilities for each hero, throwing players into a fast-paced world in which anything can happen!

item.description:
Slalom is a paper-and-pencil game for "any number" of players. Each player has a sheet with a point grid and a slalom course through it. A turn consists of rolling the dice and choosing one of three movement options. Players must pass each gate on the correct side.

Players mark off "seconds" for each die roll and mark off more for deviating from the ideal slalom line and for brushing a gate. The player marking off the fewest seconds wins.

The game was published in the November/December 1978 issue of GAMES.

Penny Patterns is played with thirty-six pennies on a board made up of blue and red circles. On each turn the active player flips a penny and places it in a red (inner) circle if it comes up tails and a blue (outer) circle if it comes up heads. Placing in a blue circle entitles a player to go again.

The object is to form symmetrical patterns of at least four pennies, and all the pennies on the board must be used. A point is scored for each axis of symmetry in such a pattern.

The game can be played competitively, but can also be played solitaire, with the object being to beat one's previous best score.

The game was published in the November/December 1978 issue of GAMES.

Drag Race is a paper-and-pencil guessing game for two players. Players alternate choosing the letter A, B, or C (darkening a half-circle to indicate their choice) and guessing what their opponent has chosen.

Player 1 chooses a letter and Player 2 guesses what they chose. If Player 2 guesses correctly nothing happens. If Player 2 guesses incorrectly Player 1 gets to darken scoring squares (representing speed), with the number depending on how late in the game it is (the later, the more points scored). The object is to score as many squares as possible.

The game was published in the September/October 1978 issue of GAMES.

Oil Strike! is played on a board depicting an oil field divided into areas of two, three, and four sites. Players start with one area (size depending on turn order) and claim a new one each turn as long as they last. The other thing a player does on each turn is select one of their sites and roll two dice, with a high enough roll producing oil and a lower roll condemning it to be dry.

Drilling next to producing wells (no matter who owns them) adds a point to the die roll for each such well, making it easier to strike oil. Players can (before rolling the dice) declare that they are going for double or quadruple production, which requires higher rolls.

Players score points for producing wells (more for double or quadruple wells, of course) and bonus points for getting all sites in an area to produce. The first player to reach a target score wins, or the player with the most points if no one manages that.

link.value: The 6 Pack of Paper & Pencil Games

item.description: The NineTacToe playsheet depicts nine Tic-Tac-Toe boards with numbers in the spaces; the numbers 1-27 each appear three times throughout the boards. Players take turns choosing a number and marking their symbol in the three spaces where it appears. In effect, each number choice is a play on three of the nine Tic-Tac-Toe games at once. The object is for a player to win a majority of the nine sub-games.

link.value: 5 Pad & Pencil Games People Love to Play

item.description:
In Financier (aka A Stock Market Game) players invest in six companies. These companies start with random values (1-6) and on each turn the active player must change the value of one of them by rolling two dice. They must choose one die which represents the company to change, the other die being the amount of the change, and whether the total of the two dice is odd or even determines whether the value goes up or down.

The player can then purchase up to three shares of one of the two companies rolled, using money printed on the gamesheet; no change is given and when it is used up no more purchases can be made.

The object is to have the greatest total share value and capital when the game ends, which happens when a roll can't be used (each company's value can only be changed a fixed number of times).

link.value: The 6 Pack of Paper & Pencil Games

name.value: RE: Your Brains – The Card Game

item.description:
All a zombie wants is a brain to munch.

Too bad the humans don’t want to give them up. We have all seen it before, the zombie hordes march against the panicked humans. The humans eventually entrench and rally then start blowing away the poor hungry masses of undead. But what if there was a different way? A more civilized way of resolving this tired old conflict? What if we could negotiate instead?

RE: Your Brains is based on the hit song by Jonathan Coulton.

Players take on the roles of the Zombie and the survivor negotiating the brain eating situation. The zombie just wants a hot meal and is trying to convince the survivor to open the door and be that meal, meanwhile the Survivor just wants to go about his life in peace and would love to convince the zombie to go bother some other poor fool, or better yet just stop shambling around all together. To do this players take turns making arguments based on a set of cards in their hands. The only limitation is the mood of the card played, the content is entirely up to the players.

RE: Your Brains is a fast playing two player game that is as much fun to watch as it is to play and you will often get help from the peanut gallery as you try to debate, cajole, and threaten your way to victory.

There are three aspects to playing RE: Your Brains.

1st is the rock, paper, scissors mechanic. There are three types of arguments to be made, Logical, Emotional, and Aggressive, ranging from values of 2-8. Logical arguments get a +2 bonus against Emotional arguments and -2 penalty against Aggressive, Emotional arguments get a +2 bonus against Aggressive and -2 against Logical, and Aggressive arguments get a +2 against Logical and -2 against Emotional. The bonus or penalty applies to the card being played, not the card on the stack. As long as the value is higher with the applied bonus or penalty (or neither if they're the same type of argument), you can play that card in response.

2nd is the roleplaying aspect. Every time you play a card, you must make an argument of the type of argument you played. Hence, if you're the zombie, you might make an 3 value Emotional plea of "We've always been such good friends, and I would hate to have you be ripped to shreds by some other zombies. Let me eat your brain, and I'll turn you into a zombie so we can be friends forever!" and as the survivor you might reply with a 2 value Logical argument which is actually a 4 against the previous 3 emotional and say something like "One would think if you were truly my friend you would defend me from these other zombies, or at the very least stop trying to eat my brain."

3rd is the trick-taking mechanic. To win the game, you must win 5 arguments Each player starts the argument with a hand of 5 cards and uses those cards to make their argument. When they can no longer beat the argument on the table (or if they choose not to), the last person to play a card wins that argument. You may play two cards of the same argument type to overcome an existing argument. If a player completely runs out of cards and has no more to respond to their opponent's argument, they lose.

The game takes a few rounds. In each round, all the players close their eyes except the single player. He turns on one of the selected tiles with cookies (tiles are double-sided, on each side there is another cookie). The players then open their eyes and have to point with the finger which cookie is new on the table. The first player who do this correctly will receive 2 points. Also players will have to remembers of what colour and shape had cookie which is missing. Each player have a change to receive points for remembering those two features. There is 16 cakes with 4 colours and 4 different shapes. After four round who will have to most points is the winner.

link.value: Egmont Polska "Dobra gra w dobrej cenie" series

item.description:
Five Cucumbers is a trick-taking game with the goal of NOT winning the last trick!

It's not easy. You have two choices on your turn: Take over a trick by playing a equal or higher card or you must play your lowest card. It is not enough to keep a low card in your hand for the last trick as you will also need some high cards for taking over key tricks.

The player who wins the final (seventh) trick screwed up and must take cucumbers. Each player collects their cucumbers at the end of a round, and if a player has more than five cucumbers, he is out of the game; five cucumbers is the most you can have! In this way more and more players are excluded from the game until the final two are playing for victory!

Five Cucumbers is a modern variant of the trick-taking game Cucumber (Agurk, Gurka), which is well-known primarily in Scandinavia. We are excited to bring you our new version!

item.description:
Topfrosch consists of a wooden frame, four frogs (made from coconut halves), a sand timer, and 160 marbles in four colors. Marbles represent the insects that the frogs want to catch.

Set the frame on the table, place the marbles inside, then flip the sand timer. Each player grabs his frog and pushes it through the arena, trying to get as many marbles as possible under the frog before the 30-second timer runs out.
 Topfrosch includes various scoring versions: In the kids' version, each marble counts one point. For adults, each color counts only for one player/team, while other colors are deducted. In some versions, one color counts for everyone, etc. Whoever has the most points after a round wins.

Carcassonne is a tile-placement game in which the players draw and place a tile with a piece of southern French landscape on it. The tile might feature a city, a road, a cloister, grassland or some combination thereof, and it must be placed adjacent to tiles that have already been played, in such a way that cities are connected to cities, roads to roads, etcetera. Having placed a tile, the player can then decide to place one of his meeples on one of the areas on it: on the city as a knight, on the road as a robber, on a cloister as a monk, or on the grass as a farmer. When that area is complete, that meeple scores points for its owner.

During a game of Carcassonne, players are faced with decisions like: "Is it really worth putting my last meeple there?" or "Should I use this tile to expand my city, or should I place it near my opponent instead, giving him a hard time to complete his project and score points?" Since players place only one tile and have the option to place one meeple on it, turns proceed quickly even if it is a game full of options and possibilities.

This special edition is sold exclusively by the German trade company Müller. It comes in a similar metal box as previous special editions and contains the Carcassonne base game along with the expansion set Carcassonne: Expansion 6 â€“ Count, King & Robber and Die Belagerer which is a new six-tile version of Carcassonne: Die Katharer (with new graphics but similar to the Rio Grande Games (2008) release).

item.description:
In Back Up! the object is to reduce your back pain to zero. Each turn, players pick up a card from the deck and discard, while trying to collect HEALTH cards in their hand. HEALTH cards reduce your pain, while PAIN cards increase it. ACTION cards allow players to take cards from other players, discard cards, or draw extra cards from the deck. Finally, some HEALTH cards cannot be played without a MONEY or INSURANCE card.

Players start with 5 cards, but the ACTION cards change the number of cards in your hand. Sometimes you are forced to discard cards that you need. The rules are simple, but the ACTION cards add a layer of strategy. It has a light humorous feel. There are 68 cards in a deck.

Sail your fleet of galleons to the Murky Isles, hiding place for some of the greatest pirate treasures ever buried. Roll the Buccaneer Bones (landlubbers call them "dice") to send ships out to sea. When you reach the island, you get a special bonus just for being there. But the best part is the treasure! Find the treasure and bring it back to port, then set sail again. The first pirate to bring back three treasures claims the title of "Scourge of the Seven Seas"! Arrrr!!!

Each player in Buccaneer Bones starts with six ships on the six numbered ports of his player mat; each ship is in a sailing lane that consists of a port, a sea space, and an island. On a turn, the player rolls four dice, then rerolls as many as he wants; if he now has a pair, he advances the ship matching the number rolled one space (from port to sea or from sea to island) and if he has a three-of-a-kind, he advances the appropriate ship two spaces (from port to island). When a player has a ship on an island, he receives a bonus:


 When on islands 1 or 6, he rolls one extra die; on islands 1 and 6, he rolls two extra dice.
 When on islands 2 or 5, he can add or subtract one from a rolled die; on islands 2 and 5, he can do this twice.
 When on islands 3 or 4, he can reroll any number of dice one extra time; on islands 3 and 4, he can reroll two extra times.


When a player has a ship on an island, if he has a three-of-a-kind matching that island number, the ship grabs one treasure, then returns to port.

If a player can't advance a ship, he can place his first mate (1) as a scout on an island to grant himself that power on his next turn, (2) as a thief on a treasure owned by a player with more treasure than him, giving him a chance to steal it next turn if he rolls any three-of-a-kind, or (3) as a defender to remove a thief on one of his treasures.

The game ends the round that a player collects his third treasure. If he's the only one with three treasures, he wins; if multiple players have three, then the tied player who has more ships farther from his ports wins.

Buccaneer Bones includes a couple of play variants, including rules for a solo game.

item.description:
Nine Holes is played on a 3x3 square grid in which the spaces have three different colors. Each player has three pieces which start off the board. Players take turns entering the pieces on the board and then (assuming no one has won) moving a piece to an adjacent space (including diagonally).

The object is to get all three of one's pieces into an orthogonal line or on all three spaces of one color.

link.value: Research Games, Inc. / Athol / RGI / ARC

item.description: Chase is played on a Backgammon board and uses similar movement rules. However, the setup is different and the object of the game is completely different; the winner is the player who captures all of the opposing pieces. Consequently, there is no bearing off (the board is a continuous loop) and captured pieces cannot be re-entered.

link.value: Research Games, Inc. / Athol / RGI / ARC

item.description:
Robot Commando (ãƒ­ãƒœã‚³ãƒž) is combat game for 2 players. Before fighting, each player make one's combat robot by combination of cards. Card has Three types of the Robot, Ability and Arms.

First, the player choose a Robot card. Player get Ability cards set and any Armed cards by the Robot. Equipped with Arms is limited by weight and shape.
Cards become commands for maneuver of Robot. And a card is 1 Hit Points. The damage decreases battle performance of the Robot and will destroy it.

By original card plot system, this game will not roll the dice for damage and decisions hit. The rule is simple, but game is technical and tactical.

This is indies game.

An LPS bonus mini-game.

"World War II has broken out and a single German pocket battleship is supremely poised amid Allied shipping lanes to completely disrupt Allied naval preparations. Can a single ship, at once so powerful it can crush any convoy escort encountered, and so fast it can evade any more powerful force sent to sink it, succeed and vindicate the concept? Find out with this exciting game!"

Hunt for the Graf Spee is an hex and counter game for two players. The British Player will try to locate and sink the Graf Spee. The German Player, whose sole unit it is, will try to locate and sink British Shipping while avoiding destruction. Movement is secretly plotted and units are placed on map after being successfully searched for. There is a small tactical subsystem to handle naval combat, similar to Minden Games Salvo (ships are firing full broadsides and maintaining range, or firing half broadsides and changing range)

Parker Brothers' Santa Claus Game consists of a simple race game governed by a spinner. Holiday themed toys and games appealed to present-buying adults during the holiday season. The first player, who cross finish line wins the game.

Company Leader is a company level based wargame, meaning that players are playing with company sized playing pieces. As a commanding officer you try to win the battlefield by scouting and destroying the enemy and by capturing urban areas.

Company Leader is not meant as a simulation of statistics, but as a game in which you are challenged to take the right tactical decisions in order to win. Therefore, the aim is for fairly simple rules. The game focuses on scouting, concealing and movement of your troops.

Fog of war is the root of Company Leader and this is symbolized by gaming pieces on the game board. At the start of the game your troops are not visible to the enemy, neither can you see his. You will have to scout to reveal them and keep scouting to prevent them from hiding again.

Malvern Hill is the seventeenth battle in the series and is the seventh in our Peninsula Campaign set of 1862. The Confederates have attacked the Union army at Glendale and they have again retreated south to Malvern Hill.

Combat is designed around the three factors that appear on the unit counters; these indicate the Range, Attack and Strength of the represented unit. You don’t even need any dice to play the game since a dice tile system is included with the game, but if you want to roll dice then it’s the simple six sided variety that you will require.

The game board is designed to be used either 2 dimensionally as a straight print and play or 3 dimensionally, this takes a little more time to construct but it is well worth the effort for the impressive game board you get at its completion. The final 3D game board gives a realistic feel to the terrain and shows the tactical dispositions of all the game counters.

It's the year 2124. Energy has become a rare commodity as a consequence of the industrialization of our universe. One of the main energy sources is White Ranium. The large energy companies can hardly find new planets with the raw material, and heavy-duty surface scanners are employed to search for a worthwhile volume of the energy source in the few Ranium mines already known.

Now the Mega Group Troll Factory Unlimited has found some on planet GH-328. Several rival mine crews have been sent to the mine to find the White Ranium and transport it to the space loader — but the material isn't secure until it arrives at the space loader. Until then it can be intercepted by the other mine crews.

In TF22 Mine, each player takes the part of one mine crew, collects White Ranium in the mine, and transports it to the space loader. Each space loader can load up to two units of White Ranium. The mine crew must then return to the base camp in the middle of the mine to recharge their equipment. After that, they can send more units of White Ranium to the space loader. The crew then uses the molecular transporter of the space loader for transport to the base camp.

The player who first transports three units of White Ranium to the space loader wins.

Unità di Soccorso Giapponesi (Japanese Rescue Teams) is a cooperative game portraying the aim of the Japanese Rescue Teams to save and protect the Japanese population from the dangers which can occur in the Japanese cities, like earthquakes, typhoons, tsunamis and nuclear pollution. This game is in memory of all the people died during the March 2011 Japanese earthquake and tsunami.
Each player represent a Japanese Rescue Team and will try to solve the problems ariring in the Japaed on the map.

The objective of the players is to reach the level 8 of the Level of Saved Lifes Track (LSL) depicted on the map, which means having saved most of the affected population and thus avoiding to reach the level -7, which would mean the loss of too many lives.
Each player chooses its set of Japanese Rescue Teams (JRT) and deploy the Team 1 in a city on the map. All the Problem Tiles are put in a cup and shuffled together.
The Sequence of play is like the following:
The playing player rolls the d12 die: if the result is 1-6 a new Problem arises (go to c); if the result is 7-12, no new Problems! (go to e.)
c. Roll the d12 die to see in which city the Problem occur (each city has a name and a reference number)
d. Take one Problem Tile form the cup, see which kind of problem is shown and put it near the city rolled during c.
e. Every Player can move his/her JRT in any city shown in the map, normally where there is a Problem or Ruins; there he/she tries to solve a Problem, starting from the playing Player.
A JRT can try to solve one Problem per turn, so if there is more than one Problem Tile in a city, the playing Player must choose which one will be tried by his/her JRT.
If the JRT manages to resolve the Problem, raise by 1 level the LSL Track, turn the Problem tile on the Ruins side.
If the JRT does not manage to solve the Problem, the Problem remains and at the start of the next turn, will decrease the LSL:
The players have to clear Ruins in order to avoid negative DRM in solving the Problems.

A nice small cooperative game!

Norsgard; is a tabletop wargame set in the cold realm of Isbran - a land of ice and fire. The players in this game play out the skirmishes of small bands of warriors led into battle by heroes.
 "During the game the situation changes rapidly - until you have secured your victory, you can never be sure of it. React to your opponents actions, block their charges, and keep them from blocking yours at the crucial moment. Play Special Cards to turn the tide of battle to give yourself the advantage and when combat commences, choose the right Tactic and push your enemies onto the defensive. From turn to turn build your dominance and win combats so that the initiative stays with you. Press your opponent until you reach your goals. Together, create an epic battle in which every warrior plays their part!

 
"Never again will you have to depend on a single dice roll - in this game you literally roll a handful. Watch as they shape the fate of your warriors and thanks to simple, easy-to-learn mechanics you will be able to concentrate on your strategy instead of trying to remember an obscure rules technicality.
 "Create your own saga, direct your heroes, and influence their future. In many cases the players will decide the fate of their characters; in big tournaments and during fierce battles they may acquire legendary artifacts or gain experience - become a great leader, a fearsome warrior - or they may perish... Norsgard awaits it's heroes, and always remember:
 Fortune favours the bold!

item.description:
Glendale is the sixteenth battle in the series and is the sixth in our Peninsula Campaign set of 1862. The Confederates are in a position to attack the Union army who is retreating towards Harrison's Landing on the James River. Combat is designed around the three factors that appear on the unit counters, these indicate the Range, Attack and Strength of the represented unit. You don’t even need any dice to play the game since a dice tile system is included with the game, but if you want to roll dice then it’s the simple six sided variety that you will require.

The game board is designed to be used either 2 dimensionally as a straight print and play or 3 dimensionally, this takes a little more time to construct but it is well worth the effort for the impressive game board you get at its completion. The final 3D game board gives a realistic feel to the terrain and shows the tactical dispositions of all the game counters.

In this board game of ancient colonization for 2-5 players, pilot your ship of colonists to an unknown Mediterranean shore and establish colonies in fortuitous locations. Establish a colony as soon as possible or pursue the ideal location. Establish close to others to enhance trade, or remain safe and remote. Re-invest to grow your colonies or pursue those of others. Send your ship home or use it in the new waters. Create more colonies or thrive safely behind strong walls. Negotiate the path between speedy growth and the disruption it causes.

A war game of building up a civilization including a modular board, variable powers and a rich set of heavily-researched cards providing special powers.

Trivia Louisville is a simple roll-and-move game featuring trivia about Louisville, Kentucky. Players move their tokens around the board answering questions from different categories. Once a player has a correct answer from each category they must pass the finish square to win the game.

From the back of the box:

What Louisville-born actor starred in the film series "Cannon" and "Jake and the Fatman?"

In 1941, Louisville was the world's largest producer of what man-made product?

Who was the first woman to ride in the Kentucky Derby?

The answers to these questions and MORE can be found inside Trivia Louisville! Trivia Louisville is an exciting new game about Louisville designed for all ages. You'll enjoy this entertaining way to discover the real intrigue inside Louisville!

name.value: Pearl Harbor Attack Balls: DARTS – Cards

item.description:
This is a real naval war game with a unique twist - it uses DARTs and BALLs to play. Players will attack nicely illustrated battleship profiles by tossing and dropping darts along with rolling balls. While tradition pointed darts can be used, the more graphic play uses dart(s) or ball(s) dipped in washable collorinfg for graphic splatters that mimic highly visual and realistic explosions. The game can be very simple dart toss game or be more complex by using the written game guide rules. Game play utilizes an eraser head dart but players can choose their own metal/plastic point type darts. The duration of play is between 20 minutes to more than an 60 minutes, depending if you play one, two, or all three parts. You can play the game in teams, family play or solo. A great game for adults and kids above the age of seven.

Game Parts Include: Target Illustration are legal size (8.5" X 14") black-gray-white (gray scale) colored prints - they are reproducable for non-commercial home/classroom use by the game purchaser

•Top View - Battleship target illustrations include the USS Arizona, USS Neveda, USS California, USS Tennessee, USS Maryland, USS West Virgnia, USS Oklahoma, & USS Pennsylvania

•Side View - Battleship target illustrations include the USS Nevada, USS Arizona, USS West Virginia, USS Oklahoma, and the USS California

•One mini ball and one eraser head dart included
•Game guide

The game shipped regular USPS mail in a sealed 2"w X 16"L tube

Note: Upgrade to the larger 11" X 17" colorized version of the paper battleship target illustrations for an additional $20 - email me for this upgrade option

User Summary

'Wie gehen die Geschäfte? Ein Unternehmerspiel voll Spannung und Humor' was published by Haus Hachenburg in the 1950s or 1960s in Germany. Another edition can be found published by SALA (Sala-Spiele GmbH & Co.)

A game reflecting the economic miracle in Germany. Similar to Monopoly you can buy/build businesses, starting from a 'Milchgeschäft' (dairy) over a 'Konfitüren-Geschäft' (jam business) to the most expensive 'Leihbücherei' (library). The player with the most money in the end wins.

[From the back of the box]

Two fun games with a colour fact pack.

Beautifully illustrated colour fact pack includes details on 24 dinosaurs.

4 collectable playing pieces from the Original Monsters in my Pocket range.

Two great games on a double sided board bring the Age of the Dinosaurs back to life!

The Dinosaur Dig - Simple collecting game for younger children who have to collect the pieces to build up a dinosaur.

Escape from the Volcano - Exciting dinosaur battle using the colour fact pack - can you beat the other dinosaurs and escape the exploding volcano?

Fun to play, and full of fascinating facts!

[Details on each game]

The Dinosaur Dig - Players roll the die and move around the board attempting to land on the dinosaur dig locations. Landing on a dig location enables the player to draw a "dig" card which contains one of the four dinosaur pieces that they need. Players get to keep any pieces they find that they don't already have but must return duplicates of pieces they already have. The first player to collect all four pieces is the winner.

Escape from the Volcano - Players roll a die and move their dinosaur figures around the outer track trying to land on the challenge squares. Landing on a challenge square allows them to challenge all the players to a dino-duel. The type of challenge square determines what ability the challenge is testing. Players then select a dinosaur "fact" card from their hand to enter the challenge contest. The player whose dinosaur card has the highest value in the challenge ability wins and they move their counter one space away from the volcano on the volcano track. The player who is the first to have their counter reach the tenth space on the volcano track has escaped the volcano is the winner.

A rift has opened, and unearthly creatures from an alien dimension are streaming into the world. They threaten the planet and the existence of the human race. Defend humankind against the perilous alien invasion as the Marine player! Or, on the other hand as the Portalist player, show those mortals they stand no chance!

Mission: Combat! is a tactical sci-fi card game for two players, one commanding the human Marines and the other representing the alien Portalists. Both have unique characteristics and abilities available only to their respective faction. In general, the Marines can perform ranged attacks and have strong firepower and good defensive positions. The Portalists, on the other hand, can deploy units for free, and their units can move quickly. Additionally, the area cards of the game board grant special abilities to the player who controls them. When a player manages to eliminate all enemy units on his turn, the game ends and that player wins.

To set up the game, players determine a start player, draw five unit cards to their hands, and take alternating turns to bring those units into play on their area cards. Then the game begins, with the start player using two action points (AP) in his first turn. In each subsequent turn, players have four action points at their disposal, which can be spent to carry out the following actions in any order as often as desired:


 Draw a card
 Play a card
 Move a unit
 Attack


In addition to the actions above, players can get free actions and bonuses from the area cards they control and can use special abilities that are available only to their faction only. Units are one of three types — Regular, Elite, or Colossal — and can attack only one unit type. For instance, an Elite unit that can deal damage to Regular units cannot deal damage to Elite or Colossal units.

To achieve victory, players need to consider the defense and attack types of their army, and the faction strengths and weaknesses, along with the abilities that they get from the terrain that they control. Choose your side and wipe your opponent from the surface of the planet!

item.description:
Atomic Race is played on a 5x5 board. Each player starts with ten pieces occupying the two rows closest to them. A move consists of taking a single piece or the top piece from an "atom" (stack) and moving it in any combination of forwards and sideways moves until it reaches an empty space or a space with an opponent's piece visible (moving through spaces where the player's own color is visible).

The central row of the board (the "plasma zone") cannot contain atoms, so a single piece there controls its space until it moves.

The object is to exit one's pieces off the opposing end of the board. Since the game is short, the designer suggests playing a series of games using a scoring system.

The game was published in the March/April 1979 issue of GAMES.

Based on the song by Jonathan Coulton, Re: Your Brains pits 2-5 players against each other and the zombie horde. Players play food and office supply cards face up in front of them to give them bonuses, play weapon cards to destroy zombies, and play any card face down in front of their opponents to create more zombies that want to eat their brains.

Each player starts out as a heroic human and can win if they are the sole survivor, OR they can become overrun by zombies and become a zombie master. Each zombie master has a different victory condition.

This game should not be confused with the other card game of the same name. Same inspiration; different implementation.

item.description:
XandO is played on a 6x6 square grid. The game begins with the players taking turns to blacken four squares of the grid (two each). After that the players take turns to mark their symbols (X and O) in empty squares, with the option of blackening a square instead on their last turns.

Once the grid is full players score for consecutive lines of their symbols in any direction. However, while even numbers of symbols score positively, odd numbers (greater than one) score negatively.

A game consists of two rounds. In the second round of a game, the same four squares are blackened as were chosen at the start of the first round and the player who went second now goes first.

The game was published in the March/April 1979 issue of GAMES.

Quink is played using five pieces each of five different colors on a 7x7 board. At the start of the game the pieces are arranged in cross formations on specific board spaces, with each cross containing one piece of each color and the center of each cross being a different color.

A move consists of a player moving a piece orthogonally any number of empty spaces. There are five special spaces which when landed on let the player make another move with the same piece or a piece of the same color, counting it as part of the same move.

The object is to get the five pieces of each color in a connected group. The game can be played as a solitaire puzzle or by multiple players; the designer suggests playing with two by trading off setting up boards for the opponent (the goal being to solve the opponent's puzzle in fewer moves than they solve yours), or any number by each trying to solve the same puzzle in the fewest moves.

Battle is a small, simplified version of Battle: The Game of Generals. The players each have six infantry and four armor units, which they secretly set up at opposite ends of a 9x12 hex grid. On a turn a player may move any or all of their pieces and can eliminate an opponent's piece by getting a greater combat value of pieces adjacent to it. Combat values are different in the three different terrain types.

The object of the game is to move a piece into the opponent's headquarters space.

The game was published in the 'May/June 1981 issue of GAMES.

Order and Chaos is played on a 6x6 square grid. On a turn a player writes either an X or an O in any empty space. The object of the first player (Order) is to complete a line of five Xs or five Os in any direction. The object of the other player (Chaos) is to prevent this.

The game was published in the September/October 1981 issue of GAMES.

item.description:
Unruly! is a party card game for all ages, where the object is fairly simple, but the rules are constantly changing, and the laughter is infectious!

In theory, winning the game should be easy. You just have to play a complete sequence of 3 Thing Cards, but getting there isn't so simple.

There are several obstacles that can, and will, get in your way.

The rules change with every player’s turn - rules ranging from silly to downright hilarious! Breaking a rule comes with a Penalty. Players draw a Penalty roll, with the results ranging from losing just one card, to losing everything and having to start from scratch.

There are Event Cards like "Switch places with another player" or "Take a Hike" where everyone leaves their cards and moves over one place. These are great for messing with the other players.

And there are Unruly Cards, which players can use at any time, when they catch another player doing the behavior or action listed on the Card, forcing the other player to make a Penalty roll.

You’re kept on your toes 100% of the time. You always have something to do, even when it’s not your turn. Your plans and progress can change with the drop of a card or an errant scratch of your head.

Competition can be fierce, yet you’ll laugh so hard that everyone will feel like a winner!

War of the Black Holes is played on a board with four concentric rings of spaces. Each player has a single spacecraft piece which moves each turn, either within a single ring or with one change to an adjacent ring. The number of spaces that can be moved depends on the ring the move ends in, with the inner rings requiring faster movement than the outer rings.

After moving a "black hole" piece is placed in a space adjacent to one's spacecraft. These pieces can be moved over but a move cannot be ended on one; a player wins when their opponent cannot move to an empty space.

The game was published in the July/August 1982 issue of GAMES.

Loop-the-Loops is played on a piece of paper on which one player draws five intersecting loops (or more if desired), in any way they want.

Players then on their turns start at an intersection and color the lines, going past two intersections and ending at a third. It is possible to switch to another loop at an intersection. The first player can start at any intersection; after that each player must start where the previous player ended.

If the coloring reaches an intersection which can't be moved from the player's turn ends and the other player may start anywhere.

When a played finishes a loop they score 1 point (or 2 points for the last loop if there are an even number of loops).

The game was published in the November 1982 issue of GAMES.

Rondo is played on a board of five concentric rings of twelve spaces each. One player has black pieces and starts on the innermost ring, the other has white pieces and starts on the outermost ring. The object is to connect the innermost and outermost rings with an unbroken chain of your pieces.

Pieces can move outward, inward, diagonally inward or outward, or around the ring they are in. However, Black can only move outward and clockwise and White can only move inward and counterclockwise. Pieces must jump opposing pieces when able to do so (the jumped pieces are not captured).

The game was published in the December 1982 issue of GAMES.

Score Five is played on a 6x6 square grid in which someone has randomly placed the numbers 1-9, four times each.

The first player starts by circling the number in one of the four corners and starting a running total with that number. The second player circles an adjacent number and adds it to the running total. This continues until the running total reaches 170, at which point the game ends.

When a player makes the running total a multiple of five, they add that running total to their score. Whoever has the higher score when the game ends, wins.

The game was published in the January 1983 issue of GAMES.

Rescue is played on a 5x9 grid. Players each have nine pieces which begin the game in stacks of one, two, or three pieces.

On a turn a player moves one of their stacks as many spaces as the number of pieces in the stack, in any orthogonal direction or combination of such directions. Only empty spaces can be crossed; an opponent's stack can be landed on, which captures the pieces in it.

After moving a player may take one piece and put it in any legal space (empty or on top of one of their one or two-piece stacks).

Certain spaces on the board have numbers in the players' colors. If a player ends a stack's move on a space of their color and the number of pieces in the stack, the stack is "rescued" and removed from the board.

The game ends when one player has no pieces on the board (due to rescue and/or capture). The player who rescued the most pieces wins.

The game was published in the February 1983 issue of GAMES.

Sque-e-e-eze Play is played on a 7x7 square grid. Players begin by each making a (different) mark in any space. On each subsequent turn, a player begins at their last mark, moves any number of empty spaces in any straight line, and places a new mark in the end space. (The previous mark is crossed out.)

The object is to end on your opponent's last mark (an exception to the rule about only moving in empty spaces) or prevent your opponent from playing.

The game was published in the May 1983 issue of GAMES.

Breakthrough is played on a 5x9 board. Each player has ten pieces which start in the rows nearest them. The object is to get a piece to the row farthest away from you. On a turn a piece can move any distance diagonally as long as it does not pass over any piece or land on an opponent's piece.

The fourth and seventh rows of the board are "wall" rows, and pieces which reach the opposing wall cannot move forward. The only way to get a piece across the wall (necessary to win) is via explosion. Each space has a maximum capacity (depending on which column it is in), and when you get that many of your pieces in a space it explodes, sending the pieces to orthogonally adjacent spaces. Opposing pieces can be captured this way, and chain reactions can occur.

The game was published in the January 1984 issue of GAMES.

2 player game played on the spaces of an 8x8 board.

Materials

4 chess pawns, 2 black and 2 white.
64 bi-colored reversi pieces.

Definition
piece = a bi-colored reversi piece

Setup

Set the empty board between the players.

Set two like color pawns diagonally adjacent to each other onto two of the four center squares on the board.

Set two pieces at each row and column along the outer edge of the board .

Play

One player plays black the other white.

Black moves first, then play alternates.

On your turn,

Move a friendly pawn in a straight line orthogonally or diagonally ending the movement on an empty square. Then take a piece from the outer edge of the board, flip it to your color and move this piece in a straight line orthogonally ending the move on an empty space. The piece last moved and the pawn last moved should now be in line of sight of each other.

When both players pass in succession the game ends.

Restrictions

- A piece is not in line of sight with a pawn if another pawn or piece is in-between them.

- Neither a pawn nor a piece may jump over another pawn or piece.

Objective

The player with the most pieces in his color on the board at the end of the game is the winner.

The inspiration for this game comes from Walter Zamkauskas Amazons

Swish and its twin game Squeeze are non-mancala bead capture games. They are played on a base-5 hex hex board divided in a 37-cells inner area and a 24-cells edge. One player makes an initial setup with three 'hex rooks' of both players on the edge and 19 beads in the inner area. The other player may choose either to move first or the color to play with.

In Swish the rooks capture by the long leap. They may capture both beads and pieces, though not simultaneously. Multiple captures are possible. The player who captures 10 or more beads wins.

The game was published in the July 1984 issue of GAMES.

Morro is played on an 8x8 square grid using two pieces per player and 19 neutral pieces. To start the game one player places all four players' pieces on the edge of the board and any number of neutral pieces on non-edge spaces. The other player may then either move first and choose which color to play, or may take the remaining neutral pieces (counting towards the victory condition) and let the other player choose a color and move first.

A turn consists of moving either of your pieces in any straight line over empty spaces. After a move, if the moving piece and any other piece (including one of the opposing pieces) enclose an unbroken line of neutral pieces (or opposing pieces), the enclosed pieces are captured.

The object of the game is to capture a majority of the 19 neutral pieces.

As a variant, one piece of each player moves as described above, and the other can jump over pieces (jumped pieces are not captured).

The game was published in the July 1984 issue of GAMES.

Crazy Quilt is played on a 4x4 grid of squares, with each square being divided into four triangles. Players take turns coloring triangles (with each player using a different color). When all triangles have been colored, players score points for certain shapes made from four triangles each, with overlaps allowed.

The game was published in the January 1985 issue of GAMES.

Pencil Football is played on a sheet of lined paper. The lines are numbered along one edge, goals are drawn near the ends, and then irregularly-spaced line segments are drawn along the lines to create obstacles.

Kick-offs, extra points, and field goals are accomplished by placing a pencil at a certain point, closing your eyes, lifting the pencil, and attempting to bring it down as close as possible to the goal line (for a kick-off) or in the goal area (for a field goal or extra point).

Regular plays are done by placing the pencil at the spot where the ball is, closing your eyes, and attempting to draw a path towards the goal that avoids obstacles. Each player gets four chances (downs) to advance the ball in this way, then the opponent takes over.

The game can be played solitaire using a provided board.

The game was published in the January 1987 issue of GAMES.

Max is played on an 8x8 grid filled with positive and negative integers, except for one space marked with a star. One player starts by crossing out any number in the row with the star and adding to his or her total. The other player then crosses out any number in the column where the first player's number is. The players continue choosing numbers based on the row or column where the previous play was until one of them cannot move.

A game consists of two rounds; in the second round players switch so that the player who played rows now plays columns and vice-versa. The high score after both rounds wins.

The game was published in the April 1994 issue of GAMES.

The game appears to be nothing more than a pencil-and-paper version of Mattix, which was not designed by the "designer" of this game.

The Great Snark Rescue is played on a hex map depicting a park. Certain hexes are designated as starting spaces for snarks, snark trackers (which are owned by the players), and transportation pieces. On each turn players move their trackers and attempt to land them on snarks, which rescues them. The object is to rescue the majority of the snarks.

The terrain affects movement; a tracker must stop when entering a forest hex and cannot normally enter water hexes. A tracker can move onto a transportation piece and then use it, which may let it move farther (e.g. a bicycle can move any distance, but only along a path) and/or circumvent movement restrictions (e.g., a boat can go in the water and a hot-air balloon can cross water and forest hexes).

Variants allow for free setup of the various pieces.

The game was published in the first issue (April/May 1995) of Zigzag, a GAMES spin-off for children.

name.value: Lost Legacy: Hyakunen Senso to Ryu no Miko
Lost Legacy: Hundred-year War – Dragon Maiden

item.description:
Lost Legacy: Hyakunen Senso to Ryu no Miko includes two sets of 16 cards: Vorpal Sword and Staff of Dragons. Players can use one set or the other or combine them in various ways to alter the powers available in the game. Shuffle all the cards together (other than the second "Lost Legacy"), and you can include up to six players in the same game. Cards from Lost Legacy: Hyakunen Senso to Ryu no Miko can also be combined with Lost Legacy and Lost Legacy: Binbo Tantei to Inbo no Shiro.

				
					Rules Summary

In Lost Legacy: Hyakunen Senso to Ryu no Miko, you start the game with one card in hand from a deck of sixteen cards. On a turn, you do the following:


 Draw: Draw the top card from the deck and add it to your hand.
 Play: Choose one of the two cards in hand to play and place it face up in front of you.
 Effect: Carry out the played card's effect, after which the card is considered as discarded.
 End: If there is at least one card left in the deck, the turn goes to the next player; if not, the investigation phase starts. Using the investigation speed indicated on the card each player has in hand, players take turns guessing which player (whether yourself or someone else) holds the "Lost Legacy" card; this card might also be in the "Ruins", a location that holds one card at the start of the game and possibly acquires more cards during play. The player who guesses correctly wins; if no one finds the Lost Legacy, then everybody loses.

item.description:
In Ore: The Mining Game, players assume the roles of clever industrialists competing for fame and fortune. Ore takes place during the industrial revolution, and aims to simulate the complexities of effective supply chain management.

Players take turns carefully placing their workers on one of several locations:
- In mines, to collect one of five different resources (lead, coal, copper, iron, or gold);
- In distribution, to secure lucrative contracts that allow for players' operations to scale.

Each player starts with $5+ and 4 workers. Early on, players have very limited means. However, by mining resources, acquiring assets, securing contracts, and expanding their operations through new initiatives, players become more readily able to generate more and more amounts of income.

Mines become exhausted after they have been mined for a certain number of turns, and, once exhausted, they are replaced by subsequent mine cards. Similarly, a limited number of assets, initiatives, and contract cards are available for players to take, and, after being acquired, they are replaced until their respective decks run out.

The game ends at the end of Turn 7.

At that point in time, the player with the greatest amount of victory points from buildings, Money, and completed contracts is declared the winner.

item.description:
Tyrant Soul pits a group of unique and powerful heroes against against a variety of encounters that evoke the feeling of an epic, set-piece "boss fight." Each challenging encounter requires long-term strategic thinking, precise tactical execution and optimal usage of resources to conquer.

Tyrant Soul was inspired by end-game raiding popularized by MMOs, but also draws influences from a diverse collection of RPGs, miniatures skirmish games and TCG/LCGs - along with its own mechanics, including (optional) digital integration features.

Key Features:
> Tile-based battle map makes for a different battlefield in every encounter.
> Each playable character has a unique skillset and mechanics that make them play differently from the others. From the rapid-fire, combo-based style of the fiery Kindleborne to the reality-bending Traceless who leaves behind "shadow copies" of herself that can copy her attacks and movements.
> Gather power from the "Soulstream" that permeates the world (represented by a set of poker-like cards with custom suits) - put together the right combinations to activate powerful Heroic versions of your base skills that add new twists and enable new combos.
> The "recharge" mechanic is a quick, intuitive and visual take on cooldown mechanics popular in video games.
> 5+ epic boss monsters and encounters - each with its own theme and mechanics
> Every encounter follows an "AI script" with a combination of set and randomized events to create a dynamic challenge - no "GM" or "Overlord" needed. Digital extensions make it a snap to run the encounter from a tablet, smartphone or laptop.
> Compete with other players around the world by taking on special, super-difficult "achievement" challenges. Our online leaderboard will ensure that everyone knows your accomplishments.
> Playable as a modular single session game or an extended campaign where players grow in power and attain new powerful items and skills.
> Expanding World: New boss encounters and character classes to be released regularly!
> Alternate Game Modes: Take on your friends in PvP combat, or enter the Gauntlet and face an endless horde of randomized foes

Allegiance: A Realm Divided is a fully self-contained game of strategy and epic fantasy battles, where players assume the roles of powerful heroes fighting for dominion over the realm.

Each hero represents a different fantasy character class, with their own unique abilities, weapons, and play styles. Players level-up their hero by unlocking increasingly powerful abilities, enlist allies to fight by their side, and engage their enemies in battle.

With 10 different playable heroes, a wide range of strategic moves to choose from, and a high degree of player-interaction built in, a game of Allegiance will never play out the same way twice.

Featuring a hybrid card game and board game format, Allegiance has all of the depth of a collectible card game in one box. Rich in detail and beautifully depicted by some of the leading fantasy artists in the industry, Allegiance is an immersive experience for fantasy fans and strategy gamers alike.

In Dig Mars, players perform different actions to dig out discovery tiles. Discovery tiles are worth varying numbers of fortune points, but fortune points can also be used to upgrade a player's equipment. When to do what? Timing is key. The different actions are:


 Move – move one of your tokens to an adjacent stack in a horizontal or vertical direction.



 Dig - reveal the top tile of the stack with at least one of your tokens on it. 



 Carry out – choose any revealed tile with at least one of your tokens on it and take it into your possession, giving you fortune points.



 Upgrade – pay the corresponding number of fortune points (by discarding tiles) to boost your equipment tile to the next level (e.g., from 2 to 3).


When a player has collected a certain amount of fortune points, depending on number of players, the game ends and he wins!

item.description:
The highest decision-making organ in a city is the City Council, which lays down the general operative and financial outlines for a city and decides on its main objectives. The true power, however, is a little further down the hierarchy in the different councils working under the City Council.

In the card-driven game Councils & Contracts, the players act as developers who try to push their own objectives — namely, receiving lucrative building contracts. Therefore, it's important for them to gain influence in every one of the councils since doing so is crucial for deciding the assignment of building contracts. Naturally, all of the developers are keen to gain that influence...

Councils & Contracts is the winner of the third game author's competition "Edition Kofferspiele" organized by Mücke Spiele/Spielmaterial. In that competition the limitation was that the game fits in 11 x 7,5 x 3 cm metal box. Similar to Hart an der Grenze smuggling boxes. It is easy and light to take with you and has a lot of game inside the box.

Components:

 1 City Hall card
 5 Council cards
 25 Influence cards (5 per player)
 36 Building project cards
 30 Employees (6 in 5 different colors)
 5 Point markers (in 5 colours)
 25 Transparent markers (to track influence)
 1 Score board




Basic gameplay:

Players start with four workers and can lose or gain more through actions.

There are four possible actions but only two of them are available depending whether player has workers in his play area or not.

If a player has workers on his play area he must place them either on council rooms (two in one council room or one in three council rooms) or start a building project using influence and depending on project one or two workers.

If a player doesn't have any workers he must take them out either from one council room (giving influence to each player with presence in that room) or finish a building project and take the depicted building action, which usually returns the workers back to players playing area.

There are eight buildings projects shown and after the building deck is depleted and only four building projects are shown the game ends. There are then two extra actions per player and final scoring.

Game variants:

First/short game: Remove cards 29 - 37 and the promos.

Mixed setup: After shuffling the A and B decks (separately) remove four cards from both of them.

Gears council: Use the gears (brown) council like the 5 player council instructs but receive gears influence.

item.description: Is this typically German or what? In the party trivia game Typisch Deutsch?! Das Kaya Spiel, developed in collaboration with comedian Kaya Yanar, players travel throughout Germany examining peculiarities of different regions, culture, language and customs.

Mirror, mirror on the wall, who is the fairest one of all? Of course, me! In Pretty Ugly every player thinks so, but only one will be declared the next top model by the strict jury.

Pretty Ugly is a satirical game about beauty contests and Top Model TV shows. The game is interactive, funny, and contains a good mixture of strategy and luck. The game mimics the absurd real-world beauty mania: players can never completely reach the beauty ideal, the beauty ideal changes over time, and finally, beauty sells!

In Pretty Ugly the players represent models that want to win as many beauty contests as possible. Each turn a player either takes 3 open cards to add to their hand, or plays an action from the hand to adapt their looks to the random (and maybe not so “pretty”) beauty ideal. But be careful: other players can be mean and “uglify” you! After three rounds there is always a beauty contest where the player with the most matching aspects with the beauty ideal wins the most money, and the player with the least matching aspects wins the least money. Then the beauty ideal changes completely and players need to adapt to the new ideal again. After 9 rounds and 3 beauty contests, the player who has won the most money in total wins the game.

Will the pressure get to you, will the crowd boos put you off or will you hold your nerve like a champion forward and put it through the middle of the big sticks for a 6 pointer to hear the crowd go wild?

item.description:
Mobscenity is a card game where players take turns picking 2 seemingly innocent words from the deck to create a Mobscenity Phrase. Each player then tries to come up with the most obscene definition for the phrase. The game can be downloaded for printing under a Creative Commons license.

The oldest player starts in the role as the Master and take six cards from the deck. The Master chooses two cards from her/his hand and places them face up on the table. These two cards become the Mobscenity Roots. The Master then states what the Mobscenity Phrase will be by combining the two terms. For example, if the Master plays the cards “Wax” and “Dolphin,” the Master can state the Mobscenity Phrase is “Waxing the Dolphin.”

The other players are given 3 minutes to write both 1) a definition of the Obscenity Phrase and 2) a sentence that includes the Obscenity Phrase (the Master can decide to boot people from the round if they do not finish on time). When the time is up, each player folds up their written response and puts it in the hat. Players take turns reading the responses, and the Master decides which response s/he likes the best. The player with the best response gets 1 point.
